Fluency For Imaging Dictation Best Practices • When dictating, keep your recording device (handheld, gooseneck, headset, etc. ) at a steady distance from your mouth to avoid fluctuations in audio quality. • Before you begin and end a recording, take a brief pause to ensure no words are cut off at the start or end. • Fluency for Imaging is optimized for various dictation environments, but it’s best to dictate in a quiet space with minimal background noise, including music

minimal background noise, including music. If you find yourself in a noisy setting or switching between different environments (from loud to quiet), be sure to recalibrate your microphone using the Microphone Wizard function. • Ensure you speak clearly in full sentences with punctuation, keeping a steady pace without over-enunciating or varying your speed too much

varying your speed too much. • Configure the speech mic to beep when recording starts and stops to ensure a clear understanding of when recording is active or inactive. Additionally, press only one button at a time on your handheld recording device. • Other fundamental practices include turning off the recording while taking phone calls and refraining from shouting into the speech mic during any interruptions

Fluency For Imaging Microphone Set up Content: • Section 1: Setting up a SpeechMike • Section 2: Calibrating your Microphone • Section 3: Calibrating your Microphone Preferences • Section 4: Troubleshooting Speech Recognition Fluency For Imaging Section 1: Setting up a SpeechMike Step 1: Launch a study from the worklist. In the bottom right corner of the Dictation Window there is an icon of a microphone. Open the icon to confirm FFI has picked up the correct SpeechMike

picked up the correct SpeechMike. Fluency For Imaging Section 2: Calibrating your Microphone Step 1: Click the Settings button from either the Job List toolbar or from the Dictation Window toolbar and select Microphone Wizard. Step 2: Open Microphone Wizard Step 3: Click the Record Button and Read the sample text presented. Use a normal voice, such as you would use to perform a dictation. The audio level will be displayed as the recording occurs

displayed as the recording occurs. The words will become highlighted in blue as you read the script. Step 4: Click Save when you are done reading to complete the microphone configuration. Fluency For Imaging Section 3: Calibrating your Microphone Preferences Step 1: Click the Settings button from either the Job List toolbar or from the Dictation Window toolbar. Step 2: Select Update Preferences. Step 3: Select Device and adjust any Microphone settings to your personal preferences

settings to your personal preferences. Hold to Talk or Toggle to Talk can also be selected in this section. Select Save and Close when a preference has been selected. Fluency For Imaging Recommended Default SpeechMike Setup: This is a diagram that displays the recommended SpeechMike set by Solventum. Fluency For Imaging Section 4: Troubleshooting Speech Recognition First Steps to Troubleshooting Bad Speech Recognition: Step 1: Recalibrate your microphone using the Microphone Wizard

microphone using the Microphone Wizard. Step 2: When there is a change in your dictation environment (e. g. going from a quiet to a loud environment), make sure to recalibrate your microphone. Step 3: Do not allow others to dictate using your own voice profile Step 4: Check the microphone privacy settings are switched to the Off position. These can be found in Privacy Settings on your PC

Privacy Settings on your PC. Fluency For Imaging Step 5: Check the Microphone volume settings are at the 70% level in sounds and settings on your PC. Step 6: If you are still experiencing speech recognition issues, make sure to reach out to support or your adoption specialist

Fluency For Imaging Template Mapping •Allocate body parts such as Head, Neck, Chest, Abdomen, Pelvis, Lower Extremity, Upper Extremity, Spine, Whole Body. •Allocate modalities such as XR, CT, BMD, MR, MAM, NM, PET, FLU, US, EOS. •Everything from mid femur down is Lower Extremity. •Everything from where the collar bone meets the breastbone to the tip of the fingers is Upper Extremity. •All oncology staging scans (e. g

oncology staging scans (e. g. CT Chest Abdomen Pelvis +/- Head +/- Neck; PSMA PET, NM Bone Scan, PET Melanoma etc. ) fall under Whole Body. CT/XR full body for multiple myeloma, radiation oncology planning, EOS scans, BMD/DEXA scans, etc also falls under Whole Body part. Essentially, anything that covers half or more of the body goes under Whole Body. •For scans that are agnostic to specific body parts, you can have a separate MISC body part

a separate MISC body part. •Will there be reports that are attached to multiple accession numbers? E. g. reports for CT Chest and X-ray Left Hand? •Have strong internal documentation of these decisions so that the ECD can evolve over time in a consistent manner, allowing rads to have strong trust that the right templates and macros will always show up for the right exams as exam codes change over time

Fluency For Imaging Vocabulary Editing Best practice for self-editing and correcting misrecognised words within Fluency For Imaging 1. Immediate Correction: When you notice a misrecognised word, immediately correct it by highlighting the incorrect word and either redictating the correct word or typing it in. 2. Fluency: Maintain fluency in your dictation. Don't pause excessively or speak too quickly. A consistent, moderate pace helps the system recognize speech patterns more accurately. 3

speech patterns more accurately. 3. Learning After Finalisation: The system learns from the corrections you make after finalizing a report. It may take 3-4 attempts for the system to learn from these corrections, so be patient and consistent with your editing. 4. Persistent Misrecognition: If a word continues to be misrecognized despite your corrections, use the "Edit My Vocabulary" feature to add the word to the system's vocabulary. This can help improve recognition in future dictations. 5

recognition in future dictations. 5. Replacement Rules: Create replacement rules for words that are frequently misrecognized. This can help automate the correction process for common errors. 6. Feedback: If persistent misrecognition issues are not resolved through the above steps, send feedback to the system administrators. They may be able to address system-wide issues or provide additional support. 7. Avoid Over-Editing: Don't over-edit minor issues that don't affect the meaning of the text

the meaning of the text. This can disrupt the natural flow of dictation and may not be necessary for the final document. 8. Review and Proofread: Always review and proofread the final document to ensure accuracy. Even with the best speech recognition technology, human oversight is crucial for catching nuances and errors that the system may miss

that the system may miss. To improve the system's recognition of words, you can follow these steps: Step 1 - Add Words to the Vocabulary Click the Settings button on the Dictation window toolbar and choose "Edit my Vocabulary. " Then, select the "Added words" button and click “Add/Train” To improve the system's recognition of words, you can follow these steps: Step 2 – Type and Record Pronunciation Type the word you want to add in the field provided

add in the field provided. Assign a Category: Select the appropriate word category (Name, Location, Medication, or Other) for the word you've added. To enhance recognition, click "Record Pronunciation" and speak the word into your SpeechMike when the button turns red. Wait for it to turn grey again to confirm the pronunciation has been recorded. Click "Save" to add the word to your vocabulary list

word to your vocabulary list. Replacement Rules Replacement Rules can be created to help improve the user experience by transforming certain phrases or words into a more suitable format. For example, using abbreviations for the full spoken word. Step 1 – Adding in Replacement Rules. Click the Settings button on the Dictation window toolbar and choose "Edit my Vocabulary. " Then, select the “Replacement Rules" button and click "Add/Train. “ Replacement Rules Step 2 – Adding in the Original word

Adding in the Original word. Enter the spoken form into the Original Word field (eg WBC). Step 3 – Adding in the Replacement word. Enter the word you would like to be displayed in the report in the Replace with field (e. g. white blood cells). Step 4 – Select Save. This replacement rule will now be added to your personal dictionary. Do’s and Don'ts for Adding Words DO add the doctor's surname only, unless the given name is unique. DO add only the misrecognized word in a phrase. DON'T add "Dr

a phrase. DON'T add "Dr. " before the doctor's name. If there are issues with recognition for these, use the "Send Feedback" feature. By following these guidelines, you can help the system learn and recognize specific words more accurately, leading to improved dictation and transcription results
